threads.author: niclas8888
threads.content: Funny. "Resource constrained" is anything less than an i386 in 1988. My first job inveolved writing an multi-task, real-time operating system, with language runtime and a serial comm network system. In 2kB RAM and 8kB EPROM (grew to 8kB RAM and 32kB EPROM in first product launch), on the 8031 (in the 8051 family mentioned above). And I went from that to making I/O devices in 1997 with a PIC16C73A, 4kB (actually 2,048 14bit wide) program memory and 192 bytes of RAM. Challenging to implement the 1-write protocol for up to 16 devices (each address is 8 bytes long), I2C, SPI, an PLC protocol called Exoline (max packet size of 240 bytes). After shitload of optimization, I proudly had 1-bit in RAM marked "Reserved for Future Use" AND found a hardware bug (and figured out a workaround) that Microchip acknowledged (Intel refused to acknowledge it when we found a similar problem in the 1980 edition of the 8031, but had been fixed in the 1982 edition) and promised me 10,000pc pricing even if I ordered smaller quantities for all future purchases. Those were days of "constrained devices".

threads.author: inx42
threads.content:
Hi everyone, I need help with following:
1. I have one STM32WLE5 module from here: https://wiki.seeedstudio.com/LoRa-E5_STM32WLE5JC_Module/
2. I have connected its VCC, GND, SWDIO, SWCLK and RST pins of it to corresponding ST-Link-v2. STCubeProgrammer connects automatically in HotPlug mode and cannot connect in Under Reset mode (see the attachment).
3.  As per OB, the RDP is Level 1, but since its not able to connect in Under Reset mode, am not able to set the RDP to AA. Here are relevant information with CLI:
---
âžœ  bin ./STM32_Programmer_CLI -c port=SWD mode=UR

ST-LINK SN  : 540030001500003141474B2E
ST-LINK FW  : V2J46S7
Board       : --
Voltage     : 3.23V
Error: Unable to get core ID
Error: Cannot connect to access port 1!  If you are trying to connect to a device with TrustZone enabled please try to connect with HotPlug mode.  If you are trying to connect to a device which supports Debug Authentication with certificate or password, please open your device using it.

âžœ  bin ./STM32_Programmer_CLI -c port=SWD mode=HotPlug -ob displ

ST-LINK SN  : 540030001500003141474B2E
ST-LINK FW  : V2J46S7
Board       : --
Voltage     : 3.23V
SWD freq    : 4000 KHz
Connect mode: Hot Plug
Reset mode  : Software reset
Device ID   : 0x497
Revision ID : Rev Y
Device name : STM32WLxx
Flash size  : 256 KBytes (default)
Device type : MCU
Device CPU  : Cortex-M4
BL Version  : 0x0
...
...

OPTION BYTES BANK: 0

   Read Out Protection:

     RDP          : 0x0 (Level 1, read protection of memories)

   BOR Level:

     BOR_LEV      : 0x0

   User Configuration:

     nBOOT0       : 0x0 (nBOOT0=0)
     nBOOT1       : 0x0 ()
...
...

---

threads.author: lbthomsen
threads.content: I guess you will have to flip the read out protection to level 0 - but you will lose whatever is in the flash doing so.  You _can_ do that with the STM32CubeProgrammer.  See https://stm32world.com/wiki/STM32_Readout_Protection_(RDP)

threads.author: lbthomsen
threads.content: Also made a video on the topic: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4nCFsfzsWqA
